title: (x) Geometric text sans w/ low x-height and vertical tail on Q - Vogue {Mark Foster}
content:
Hello all.  
I’m wondering exactly what typeface this is. It has a lot in common with Futura, but it’s an odd variation on the style. Note, the vertical cross of the Q. (Much like whatever the New Yorker uses in their “listings” section.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/mysteryletters_4392.gif)

[http://www.sweaterthieves.com/uploaded\_images/mysteryletters.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.sweaterthieves.com/uploaded_images/mysteryletters.gif "http://www.sweaterthieves.com/uploaded\_images/mysteryletters.gif")  
online image at link above.

Thanks in advance for any help.

–Jonathan

p.s. Thanks for the title edit moderators. I’ll work on that.

 [‹ (x) Unicase face in newspaper ad for Gallo wines - FF Disturbance {Forrest}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38618 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Ascension Catholic Church serif logo - Mrs Eaves {Zandt King} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38614 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Jonathan Bennett

comments.content:
Thank you Mark. That was quick.  
Too bad it is called Vogue. Any google searches will probably only yield a million items related to the famous magazine’s typography.

Oh well. This certainly helps.

Best.

JB

<cite>Too bad it is called Vogue. Any google searches will probably only yield a million items related to the famous magazine’s typography.</cite>

You can search the [Global Type database](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.global-type.org/Searching.743.0.html).

I would say Vogue Medium or Bold. H&FJ’s [Verlag](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100009) will get you close.

Can’t remember where I found this image of Vogue (Light), perhaps the old H&FJ web site:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/vogue_5075.jpg)

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/anat344_5449.gif)
 From Alexander Lawson’s <cite>Anatomy of a Typeface
</cite>
’superficially resebles Futura’, understatement, lol. It even has the odd characters in Special No. 8, like that ’r’.
Yeah, and ‘Special No. 3’ is the Kabel enhancement. Someone should do an OpenType version with stylistic subsets; the Early-20th-Century-German-Geometric-Sans-All-In-One-Font … ;°)

Yes, Stephen, thanks. I found one of those discussions while hunting around. So, another related question, how about that typeface that The New Yorker uses for their listings? Is that commercially available? Is it Vogue? It has the telltale Q.
Care to post a visual sample so we can see what you’re talking about?

Also, check out [Neutraface](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=18&subpage=viewfonts) and [Neutraface 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830094151/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=612&subpage=viewfonts). They both have that Q.
